importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2021 to 2025, during which new allegations and media attention have intensified scrutiny of Prince Andrew's relationship with Jeffrey Epstein and Virginia Giuffre, culminating in the 2025 memoir publication.

keyTakeAways: Virginia Giuffre, a former victim of sexual trafficking by Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, accused Prince Andrew of sexually abusing her multiple times when she was under 18.
Prince Andrew has long denied any sexual contact with Giuffre and claimed no memory of their meetings or a famous 2001 photograph.
A 2022 out-of-court settlement was reached between Andrew and Giuffre, with Andrew acknowledging her suffering and making a donation to her charity, but not admitting wrongdoing.
Giuffre’s memoir, 'Nobody’s Girl', was published posthumously in 2025, six months after her suicide in April 2024, and quickly became a bestseller.
The memoir alleges that Andrew’s staff tried to hire internet trolls to harass Giuffre during her legal battle, and that Epstein paid her $15,000 after her first encounter with Andrew.
The book details three alleged sexual encounters: one in London, one at Epstein’s New York home, and one on Epstein’s Caribbean private island with about eight other girls, all allegedly under 18.
New documents, including an email from February 2011, suggest Prince Andrew maintained contact with Epstein longer than previously admitted, with him stating they were 'in this together'.
The Metropolitan Police are investigating whether Prince Andrew, in 2011, asked a bodyguard to check Giuffre’s criminal record, raising further concerns about his knowledge and involvement.
In 2019, Prince Andrew stepped down from public duties and charity roles after a BBC interview where he gave inconsistent and widely criticized explanations about his relationship with Epstein.
There is growing pressure on Buckingham Palace and the UK government to strip Prince Andrew of his titles and remove him from royal residences, including the 30-room mansion near Windsor Castle.
Ghostwriter Amy Wallace, who co-wrote the memoir, stated that Giuffre's bravery in exposing the allegations played a key role in pushing Prince Andrew to step back from his public roles and titles.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The British royal family is facing renewed public scrutiny following the posthumous release of Virginia Giuffre’s memoir, 'Nobody’s Girl,' which alleges that Prince Andrew sexually abused her when she was 17, under the influence of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell. The book details three alleged encounters, including one on Epstein’s Caribbean island with multiple underage girls, and claims that Andrew’s staff attempted to hire internet trolls to discredit her. Though Prince Andrew denies all claims and previously reached a 2022 settlement that acknowledged Giuffre’s trauma without admitting guilt, new evidence—including an email from 2011 indicating continued contact with Epstein—has fueled further criticism. The UK government and Buckingham Palace are under pressure to strip Andrew of his titles and remove him from royal duties. The memoir, which became a bestseller on Amazon, underscores ongoing concerns about power, accountability, and the role of royalty in protecting victims of sexual abuse.
title: Memoir by Prince Andrew’s and Epstein’s accuser reignites a scandal that long dogged UK royals
